RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Graduada em Engenharia de Materiais pela Universidade de São Paulo (2009). Doutorado concluído em 2015 em Engenharia Metalúrgica e de Materiais na Universidade de São Paulo. Realizou estágio de pós graduação na Universidade da Califórnia (Davis, EUA). Atualmente é professora com dedicação exclusiva do Insper, lecionando disciplinas e auxiliando na consolidação do novo programa de graduação em Engenharia Mecânica, Mecatrônica e de Computação baseado em metodologias de aprendizado ativo dos alunos.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Bachelor's in Materials Engineering from Universidade de São Paulo (2009). Defended PhD thesis in 2015 in Metalurgical and Materials Engineering at University of São Paulo. Part of the PhD research project was developed at University of California, Davis under the supervision of prof. Alexandra Navrostsky.

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES: Estágio supervisionado na Cosmed, indústria de medicamentos e bens de consumo dos setores alimentício e cosmético do grupo Hypermarcas. Desenvolvimento de projetos como: melhoria de dispersão de esmaltes e levantamento de perdas no processo.

Aulas de apoio aos alunos do Instituto Mauá de Tecnologia. 
Disciplina: Materiais de Construção Mecânica

OUTRA-ATIVIDADE-TECNICO-CIENTIFICA.ATIVIDADE-REALIZADA: Coordenação de laboratório didático de Química e Materiais

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: he main difference between nanoparticles and bulk materials is the high fraction of atoms located at the interface region. While this is key for numerous applications, the Gibbs energy is conversely increased by the interface term , such that G = Gamma.A (where Gamma is the interface energy and A is the molar surface area), making the small particles highly unstable and prone to growth to decrease the total energy of the system. Size stabilization is possible when growth is hindered by controlling two main variables: diffusion and interface energy. Therefore, low synthesis temperatures, reduction in the point defects and low interface energy are possible strategies to stabilize nanoparticles. The association of the calorimetric and surface excess data can give a complete and more general view of the segregation process and the consequent energetic modification of oxide nanoparticles. This is key for the development of novel compositions with high stability for applications in agriculture, catalysts for water cleaning, and energy generation. In addition to the scientific goals, this project will bring cultural exchange to benefit UC Davis and USP students and professors by expanding the diversity of thoughts. New breakthroughs are expected by the simple mingle of the diverse team. This project will start a series of discussions and experiments on critical problems regarding nanostability of oxides. Through the exchange of people and ideas, new horizons will be developed for the understanding of nanomaterials.
